title: 115_hr2493
content: The Act may be cited as the "Conflicts from Political Fundraising Act of 2017". Congress finds that public confidence in the Federal Government relies on officers and employees avoiding conflicts of interest. Risks arise when nominees or appointees have ties to political entities. Since the 2010 Citizens United v. FEC decision, corporate political spending has significantly increased, with some contributions to 501(c)(4) entities remaining undisclosed, allowing for anonymous spending. Since the 2010 Citizens United v. FEC decision, corporate political spending has increased, with some contributions to 501(c)(4) entities undisclosed, allowing for anonymous spending. Current financial disclosure requirements do not mandate reporting donations to political action committees or entities under 501(c)(4) or 501(c)(6) of the Internal Revenue Code. Public disclosure of political spending can help mitigate conflicts of interest. Public disclosure of apparent or actual conflicts of interest is crucial for addressing conflicts through ethics agreements negotiated between the filer and the agency they will serve, as outlined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
